channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Calls Up 1,500 Troops as Tensions Mount With Hamas
item.description: Israel and the militant group Hamas seemed set on a collision course on Monday, with an escalation of cross-border clashes around the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: An Israeli missile strike hit Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza Strip, early Monday.

item.title: At War Blog: Signs of an Afghan Crisis, There on Election Day in June
item.description: Weeks after the Afghan runoff, when the election commission put the number of votes cast at 8.1 million, the vision of a more than half-empty ballot box in Kabul flashed before a reporter’s eyes.
item.dc:creator: By ALI M. LATIFI

item.title: Afghan Vote Results Are in Question, With Fraud Count Ahead
item.description: The election panel announces that Ashraf Ghani is ahead of Abdullah Abdullah by a million votes before auditing, setting the stage for a deeper dispute.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Ahmad Yousuf Nuristani, the chairman of the election commission, speaking during a press conference in Kabul on Monday.

item.title: Spy Scandal Tails Merkel All the Way To Beijing
item.description: The visit by the German leader was meant to focus on business, but attention has been on allegations of spying at home — reportedly involving the United States.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany with Prime Minister Li Keqiang of China on Monday during her visit to Beijing.

item.title: Pope Asks Forgiveness From Victims of Sex Abuse
item.description: In his first meeting with people abused by members of the clergy, Francis led a private Mass and pledged not to tolerate harm done to minors.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: L' Osservatore Romano, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Pope Francis watched as Archbishop Claudio Maria Celli, the president of the Pontifical Council for Social Communications, showed him news on a tablet on Monday at the Vatican.

item.title: Egypt’s President Expresses Disappointment Over Conviction of Three Journalists
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt appeared to raise the possibility of a presidential pardon for three journalists working for Al Jazeera’s English news channel.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: This photo released by the office of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt shows him at a meeting on Sunday in Cairo.

item.title: China Denies Entry to an American Scholar Who Spoke Up for a Uighur Colleague
item.description: The American professor said he believed he was being punished for his vocal backing of Ilham Tohti, an ethnic Uighur economics professor.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Elliot Sperling, right, an American professor, with Ilham Tohti, an ethnic Uighur economics professor.

item.title: Inside Europe: European Union Juggles Its Problem Children
item.description: The immediate task facing the European Union could be described as keeping the British in, the Russians out and the Germans down.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL TAYLOR | REUTERS

item.title: Top Iraqi General Killed in Mortar Attack
item.description: The killing occurred west of Baghdad, close to Falluja, a city that the Iraqi government has been trying to reclaim from Sunni militants for most of this year.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and SUADAD AL-SALHY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Possible Solution to Toilet Stink in China
item.description: An environmentally friendly way to combat toilet odors may allow for a more pleasant experience when nature calls.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: The chemicals used in many portable toilets are often bad for the environment and costly.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Promise of Aleppo’s Radicals
item.description: The West’s best allies against ISIS are other Sunni Islamists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MATTHIEU AIKINS

item.title: Eduard Shevardnadze, Foreign Minister Under Gorbachev, Dies at 86
item.description: Mr. Shevardnadze helped hone the “new thinking” that transformed the Soviet Union, and then led his native Georgia through its turbulent start as an independent state.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, center, then the Soviet foreign minister, with President George Bush, left, and Secretary of State James A. Baker III in the White House Rose Garden in 1989.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Thai Rice and Nigerian Politics
item.description: Hungry people are susceptible to gifts from slick politicians.
item.dc:creator: By ADEWALE MAJA-PEARCE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Taking Sides in Libya
item.description: Amid Libya’s worsening violence and polarization, room for dialogue and consensus is shrinking.
item.dc:creator: By FREDERIC WEHREY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Lawyer Charged After Trying to Defend June 4 Commemorators
item.description: A public interest lawyer, Chang Boyang, has been charged with “suspicion of illegal commercial activities” after attempting to defend several attendees at a meeting discussing the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement, lawyers said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The lawyer Chang Boyang, speaking to clients he represented in China's poisoned milk powder scandal, in Zhengzhou, September 2008.

item.title: Britain to Investigate Allegations of Sexual Abuse Cover-Up Decades Ago
item.description: The investigations follows reports that scores of documents relating to child abuse in official circles went missing at the Home Office in the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Shevardnadze, Former Georgian President, Dies at 86
item.description: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, an ex-president of Georgia and former Soviet foreign minister, died on Monday after a long struggle with illness, his personal assistant said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Condemns Efforts to Play Down Japan’s Wartime Aggression
item.description: The Chinese leader warns Japan against revising history as tensions fester between the two Asian powers.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Chinese citizens gather in Chongqing to commemorate the 77th anniversary of the start of Japan's war with China.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Julia Middleton and Ronald Arculli on Cultural Intelligence in a Global Era
item.description: Who will lead the world to a better future? Julia Middleton’s new book, “Cultural Intelligence,” proposes the idea that people who can truly bridge cultures, in a fundamental, not superficial, way, will be the best leaders.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Ties Strained, Germans Press U.S. to Answer Spy Allegation
item.description: There was anger but also caution, suggesting that the scandal over the arrest of a German intelligence employee might not be as serious as feared.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in Berlin to promote her memoir, appeared on Sunday with a magazine editor, Christoph Amend.

item.title: 6 Israelis Held Over the Killing of Palestinian
item.description: A group of Israelis was arrested in what one official described as a revenge killing. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu pledged to pursue the case and said, “We do not differentiate between terrorists.”
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Tariq Abu Khdeir, 15, arrested in the unrest, is a cousin of the victim and was shown on a video being beaten by Israeli officers.

item.title: World Cup 2014: Controversies Highlight Players’ Use of Social Media
item.description: This year’s tournament is notable for a widespread use of social media by athletes eager to issue confessions, explanations and interpretations after controversial incidents.
item.category: United States Men's National Soccer Team
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: The Brazilian star Neymar addressed fans in a YouTube video after he was injured.

item.title: Ukraine Military Finds Its Footing Against Pro-Russian Rebels
item.description: Since President Petro O. Poroshenko called off a cease-fire and ordered troops to end the rebellion, an entirely different Ukrainian military appeared at the front.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: People waiting for food aid from Ukrainian soldiers on Sunday in Slovyansk, where government forces routed insurgents.

item.title: Google, Facebook, Amazon and Others Thrive Despite Objections
item.description: European consumers may criticize Facebook’s privacy policies or working conditions at Amazon, but they are still hooked on American technology companies.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Niels Ackermann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guillaume Rosquin usually shops at local bookstores in Lyon, France, but said he would go to Amazon for lower prices.

item.title: David Truong, Figure in U.S. Wiretap Case, Dies at 68
item.description: His conviction on espionage charges in 1978 raised alarms about the federal government’s use of wiretaps without court orders and spurred passage of the 1978 Federal Intelligence Surveillance Act.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: David Truong, in 1970, served five years of a 15-year sentence.
